item.title: Adding a Bank Sorter
item.dc:creator: @arham_4 arham 4
item.description:
@arham_4 wrote:

Difficulty: 1/10
What you need to know: how I do things, c&p, how to add a method, and to know what a method is(maybe…)
Purpose: to get rid of the empty slots in a bank.
Base: any older 317 [allstar, delta(might work), or others…]

1.) Open client.java
2.) Scroll all the way to the bottom. Right before the very last “}” add this method.

	public static void checkBank() {
		// sorting
		for (int i = 0; i < bankItems.length; i++) {
			if (bankItems[i] == -1)
				// bankItemsN[i]=-1;//this was a fix for the program i wrote it
				// in, i wrote it as a stand-alone which i will post at the end.
				for (int j = i; j < bankItems.length; j++) {
					if (bankItems[j] != -1) {
						bankItems[i] = bankItems[j];
						bankItemsN[i] = bankItemsN[j];
						bankItems[j] = -1;
						bankItemsN[j] = -1;
						break;
						// MODIFIED VERSION 1.1(all it should need)
						if (j == bankItems.length - 1)
							return;
					}
				}

		}
	}

What this code does is simple enough to understand.

-checkBank is the name of the method
-the “()” following checkBank means it is receiving a void (aKa. no arguments)
-the first “for” loop repeats for the length of bankItems(the max amount of items allowed in bank)
-the first if statement “if (bankItems[i]==-1)” checks if there is an item in that bank slot, if the item ID is -1 then there is nothing there(game wise)
the second for loop is nested within the first for loop and the if statement, which means it will only be called if the previous two are active/“true”. this will start another for loop “for” “(int j=i” means this for loop will start at where the first one is currently at, and continue till the same end point, or till an item is found.
-the if statement following checks if it is a real item, if it is it moved it to the first for loops position “i”, which is currently a “null / -1” item, we know this because otherwise it would have reached the second for loop “j”.

–the following move the item found in the second loop counter variable to the first loop counters location.
bankItems[i]=bankItems[j];
bankItemsN[i]=bankItemsN[j];
bankItems[j]=-1;
bankItemsN[j]=-1;

3.) Now that you have your method in there, save and compile to make sure you have no errors. make sure your brackets(" { / } ") are in the correct spots.

4.) Now that you have the method to sort your bank, you need it to be called somewhere. so search for “void fromBank(” without the "'s
In this method is where we need to add “checkBank();” to call our method. I personally add it at the very bottom of the method, mine appears rightbefore the next method “getXPForLevel(”

So I go right before the } preceding getXPForLevel( and add “checkBank();”
So now it looks like this right there.

} checkBank(); } //this is the closing bracket for the fromBank method public int getXPForLevel(int level) { int points = 0; int output = 0;
Another option would be to add it to the resetbank() method. This would have the same effect i believe.
you could add the call to the top of fromBank but then the most recent item you took out will not be sorted…
my standalone:

[code=java]
public class bank {
private static int bankItems[] = new int[300];
private static int bankItemsN[] = new int[300];
private static boolean auto_sort = true;

public static void bank2() {
	for (int i = 0; i < bankItems.length; i++) {
		if (i % 7 == 0) {
			bankItems[i] = i;
			bankItemsN[i] = i * i;
		}
	}
}

public static void disp() {
	for (int i = 0; i < bankItems.length; i++) {
		System.out.print(bankItems[i] + "\t" + bankItemsN[i] + "\t\t");
		if (i % 4 == 0)
			System.out.print("\n");
	}
}

public static void replace(int item, int with) {
	for (int i = 0; i < bankItems.length; i++) {
		if (bankItems[i] == item)
			bankItems[i] = with;
	}
}

public static void addItem(int item, int amount) {
	for (int i = 0; i < bankItems.length; i++) {
		if (bankItems[i] == item) {
			bankItemsN[i] += amount;
			return;
		}
	}
	for (int i = 0; i < bankItems.length; i++) {
		if (bankItems[i] == -1) {
			bankItems[i] = item;
			bankItemsN[i] = amount;
			return;
		}
	}
}

public static boolean deleteItem(int item, int amount) {
	for (int i = 0; i < bankItems.length; i++) {
		if (bankItems[i] == item) {
			if (bankItemsN[i] >= amount) {
				bankItemsN[i] -= amount;
				if (bankItemsN[i] == 0)
					bankItems[i] = -1;
				break;
			} else {
				return false;
			}
		}
	}
	if (auto_sort)
		checkBank();
	return true;
}

public static void checkBank() {
	// sorting
	for (int i = 0; i < bankItems.length; i++) {
		if (bankItems[i] == -1)
			bankItemsN[i] = -1;
		for (int j = i; j < bankItems.length; j++) {
			if (bankItems[j] != -1) {
				bankItems[i] = bankItems[j];
				bankItemsN[i] = bankItemsN[j];
				bankItems[j] = -1;
				bankItemsN[j] = -1;
				break;
			}
		}

	}
}

public static void main(String args[]) {
	bank2();
	// disp();
	replace(0, -1);// replaces the default 0's with an empty slot.
	addItem(50, 50);
	disp();
	deleteItem(49, 100);
	System.out.println("AFTER DELTE ITEM/AUTO_SORT");
	disp();

}

}[/code]

NOTE: I will be updating this code really soon to make it even more efficient, just working out the minor details at the moment =3

I bet this has been posted before but have only seen one server with a self sorting bank. so obviously it is not that common.

EDIT: Fix found.

It is a substantial difference, granted this may have extreme conditions
Conditions:
Every 7th item is real (rest are -1)
code:

[code] public static void checkBank() {
//sorting
for (int i=0;i<bankItems.length;i++) {

		if (bankItems[i]==-1)
			bankItemsN[i]=-1;
			for (int j=i;j<bankItems.length;j++) {
				if (bankItems[j]!=-1) {
					bankItems[i]=bankItems[j];
					bankItemsN[i]=bankItemsN[j];
					bankItems[j]=-1;
					bankItemsN[j]=-1;
					break;
				}
				if (j==bankItems.length-1) {	
					return;
				}
			}
		
	}
}[/code]

the “if (j==bankItems.length-1)” is key here. with my conditions it took it from these:
WITH SHORTCUT: 5718
WITHOUT: 38614
that is how many times counter was incremented when it didn’t need to be.

code for this output:

[code]public class bank {
private static int bankItems[]=new int[300];
private static int bankItemsN[]=new int[300];
private static boolean auto_sort=true;

public static void bank2() {
	for (int i=0;i<bankItems.length;i++) {
		if (i%7==0) {
			bankItems[i]=i;
			bankItemsN[i]=i*i;
		}
	}
}
public static void disp() {
	for (int i=0;i<bankItems.length;i++) {
		System.out.print(bankItems[i]+"\t"+bankItemsN[i]+"\t\t");
		if (i%4==0)
			System.out.print("\n");
	}
}
public static void replace(int item, int with) {
	for (int i=0;i<bankItems.length;i++) {
		if (bankItems[i]==item)
			bankItems[i]=with;
	}
}
public static void addItem(int item,int amount) {
	for (int i=0;i<bankItems.length;i++) {
		if (bankItems[i]==item) {
			bankItemsN[i]+=amount;
			return;
		}	
	}
	for (int i=0;i<bankItems.length;i++) {
		if (bankItems[i]==-1) {
			bankItems[i]=item;
			bankItemsN[i]=amount;
			return;
		}
	}
}
public static boolean deleteItem(int item, int amount) {
	for (int i=0;i<bankItems.length;i++) {
		if (bankItems[i]==item) {
			if (bankItemsN[i]>=amount) {
				bankItemsN[i]-=amount;
				if (bankItemsN[i]==0)
					bankItems[i]=-1;
				break;
			} else {
				return false;
			}
		}
	}
	if (auto_sort)
		checkBank();
	return true;
}
public static void checkBank() {
	//sorting
	int counter=0;
	boolean once=true;
	for  (int i=0;i<bankItems.length;i++) {
		
		if (bankItems[i]==-1)
			bankItemsN[i]=-1;
			for (int j=i;j<bankItems.length;j++) {
				counter++;
				if (bankItems[j]!=-1) {
					bankItems[i]=bankItems[j];
					bankItemsN[i]=bankItemsN[j];
					bankItems[j]=-1;
					bankItemsN[j]=-1;
					break;
				}
				if (j==bankItems.length-1) {	
					return;
				}
			}
		
	}
}

public static void main(String args[]) {
bank2();
//disp();
replace(0,-1);//replaces the default 0's with an empty slot.
addItem(50,50);
disp();
deleteItem(49,100);
System.out.println("AFTER DELTE ITEM/AUTO_SORT");
disp();

}

}[/code]

The reason for the once is because every time the j counter hit its max in that list it would output it on me again >_> so i would have about 10 thousand writings of the number of times it could have been done by then, which over ran my terminal so i couldn’t see the lowest one.

This in turn saved me 17 milliseconds processing time =] (WHICH ADDS UP!)
If you would like to know why this line makes a difference, please post and ask.

Code: http://pastebin.com/ZCQzertn

I fixed your conventions also btw.

Read full topic

item.title: Adding a Bank Sorter
item.dc:creator: @Togasa Togasa
item.description:
@Togasa wrote:

MrFun:

So what is a Bank sorter? im so confused on why i need this code

What this is supposed to do is whenever your bank has empty spaces it puts an item already in your bank in that empty spot…and does this until you have no more ‘open’ empty spots in your bank.
However don’t we wish everything actually ‘worked’ how it’s supposed to? Because this doesn’t work.
